page.title: 14Highbrook - Buildings
page.content: Several buildings date from the late 16th and early 17th century. It was an area of smallholdings each with a farmhouse whose occupants often needed other sources of income to subsist. When the land passed from monastic hands at the dissolution the new owners often improved their homes. Many timber-framed buildings remain. These have mostly been carefully restored and extended in succeeding centuries. Local cladding materials are mostly brick and clay tiles but there is some use of local sandstone and Horsham slates for roofing. There are three Oast houses, two in Highbrook of which one remains unconverted.
